awd_titl_txt: GOALI/Collaborative: Engineering Biofilm Dynamics for Cyanotoxins in Biological Water Treatment
awd_abstract_narration:
1605185/1605161
Seo / Mou

Threats to drinking water supplies as a result of increased frequency and duration of harmful algal blooms has been on the rise nationally and globally, for example the Lake Erie cyanobacteria bloom. To protect the public from emerging contaminants like cyanotoxins in drinking water sources, various advanced water treatment processes are considered and adopted by water utilities. This project is exploring a sustainable treatment approach using bacterially active filters to remove harmful algal bloom toxins and other chemicals of emerging concern as the first step in drinking water treatment. However, biological filtration systems for emerging contaminants are not well adopted as they commonly show either low or unmaintained biofilm activities for target pollutants. To enhance the performance of biological filtration systems, bioaugmentation and bio-stimulation were considered, but still regarded as uncontrollable as engineering approaches for consistent results. Accordingly, systematic studies are greatly needed to understand and control biofilm dynamics in biological filtration systems for emerging contaminants. 

The principal research objectives of this study are: 1) to understand the composition, activity and dynamics of biofilm community and their impact on the effectiveness of biological filtration systems in cyanotoxin removal, and, 2) to provide optimum operational parameters and monitoring tools for effective biological filtration systems operations under the pressure of source water contaminated with harmful algal bloom organisms. Research emphasis will be placed on understanding how the bacterial biofilm formation and activity, can be enhanced and maintained by engineered approaches such as bioaugmentation and bio-stimulation in order to improve performances of biological filtration systems for cyanotoxin removal. Specific objectives and hypotheses proposed are: 1) To understand the degradation dynamics (adaptation and evolution) of cyanobacteria toxin degrading bacteria for bioaugmentation or bio-stimulation applications. Hypothesis: The concentration variation of cyanotoxins and the presence of other natural organic matter and nutrients in water will affect the community and function of cyanotoxin degrading bacteria. 2) To investigate surface interactions between bioaugmented bacteria and indigenous biofilm formed on filter media (physical, chemical, and biologically mediated interactions by microbial biofilms). Hypothesis: The formation of biofilm(s) may affect not only hydrodynamics and physical properties (e.g. effective size of media) of biological filtration systems, but also the adhesion and growth of bioaugmented bacteria in biological filtration systems. 3) To determine the impact of filter operational parameters on biofilm formation, growth, and subsequent degradation of cyanotoxins in biological filtration systems. Hypothesis: Optimized operational parameters of biological filtration systems (backwashing frequency and intensity, filtration rate, and bio-stimulation) can be obtained to address various environmental factors. In addition, the proposed project will provide training and education for three graduate students as well as summer research opportunities for undergraduate and high school students. Furthermore, research findings will be introduced in PIs' outreach and service activities, for example, educational programs for under-represented K-12 students and public outreach via Lake Erie Center.

por.por_cntn:
Lake Erie is the smallest and warmest lake among the five Laurentian Great Lakes, and it has a history of eutrophication and sporadic blooms of cyanobacteria. During cyanobacterial blooms, potent cyanotoxins are released in to Lake Erie water, sometimes at levels exceed the safe use guideline published by the World Health Organization. In August 2014, a bloom event in the western basin of Lake Erie led to a shutdown of public water supply for nearly 500,000 residents in Toledo Ohio. Advanced water treatments are considered by water plants in response to this emerging concern. However, these processes typically require high energy and high cost. One environmental friendly and more sustainable option is biological treatment. One of the major goals this project was to examine potential ways to activate microorganisms in water filtration systems to removal of cyanotoxins.

The major objectives of the project were to (1) isolate bacteria from Lake Erie and screen for those that can perform microcystin degradation, (2) examine impacts of pH, temperature and nutrient supply on microcystin degradation by obtained isolates, (3) to examine microbial community structures at different steps during drinking water treatments, (4) to understand interactions between cyanobacteria and microorganisms during cyanobacterial blooms.

Bacterial isolation and testing (obj 1, 2). Our study obtained over 30 bacterial isolates that can effectively degrade microcystins (MCs), the dominant cyanotoxins in Lake Erie and other freshwaters. These isolates are affiliated with three bacterial phyla, i.e., Actinobacteria, Firmicutes and Proteobacteria. Their MC degradation activities were the highest at warm (30-35 ?C) and neutral to slightly basic (pH7-8) conditions. Rates of MC degradation were not significantly impacted by addition of organic compounds for most isolates. Obtained isolates can serve as good candidate to augment biofiltration processes in removing MCs.

Microbial community in water treatment (obj 3). Structure of microbial communities in the source water, filter backwash and sludge of a local drinking water plant were studied. Sequencing analysis revealed a diversity of bacteria (10 bacterial phyla) in collected samples, the relative abundance of each taxon varied among sampling location and time. At the family and genus levels,  Sphingomonadacea and Sphingomonas taxa were consistently abundant in all samples and had generally higher relative abundance in source water (SW) than filter backwash (BW) and sludge (SL) samples during the warm months (June to September). These taxa are known for their ability to degrade various organic pollutants, including MCs. This finding is different from previous studies in Lake Erie, which identified these taxa as minor members in MC degradation.

Interactions between cyanobacteria and other bacteria (Obj 4). We explored the co-occurrence patterns of bacteria, phytoplankton and zooplankton in water reservoirs that served as drinking water sources. Our results suggest that neutral process consistently overweighed the importance of selective processes in governing bacterial community structure during cyanobacterial bloom succession, and its relative importance was the lowest during the bloom period. Our results also indicate that cyanobacteria and bacteria are closely collaborated on nutrient transport and uptake.

Our project offered potential sustainable treatment options to water treatment facilities and furthered our knowledge on cyanotoxin production, degradation and microbial community interactions during cyanobacterial blooms. In addition, this project provided training and education for two PhD students, one MS student and four undergraduate students at Kent State University. Moreover, through this project, a close collaboration was built up between microbiologists and engineers in two research institutions.
